What a great find! Shooting with a vintage camera can be a wonderful experience, and with some practice and technique adjustments, you can achieve amazing results even in low-light conditions. Here are some tips to help you improve your low-light photography skills with your 1950s-era Canon rangefinder:

1. **Understand your camera's limitations**: Familiarize yourself with your camera's capabilities and limitations. Know its maximum aperture, shutter speed range, and ISO ratings (if it has them). This will help you make informed decisions when shooting in low light.
2. **Use fast film**: Since you're shooting with a vintage camera, you're likely using film. Choose a high-ISO film (such as 400 or 800) to increase your camera's sensitivity to light. This will help you capture images in low-light conditions.
3. **Shoot during the golden hour**: The golden hour, just before sunset, provides soft, warm light that's ideal for low-light photography. Take advantage of this time to capture beautiful, warm-toned images.
4. **Use available light**: Make the most of available light sources, such as streetlights, lamps, or candles. Position your subject near these light sources to create interesting, moody images.
5. **Open up your aperture**: Use the largest aperture (smallest f-stop number) possible to let more light into your camera. This will create a shallower depth of field, which can add to the moody atmosphere of low-light photography.
6. **Slow down and stabilize**: Low light often requires slower shutter speeds. Use a tripod or find a stable surface to rest your camera on to prevent camera shake. You can also use a shutter release cable or the camera's self-timer to minimize camera movement.
7. **Anticipate and prepare**: Scout your location beforehand to identify potential issues with lighting. Bring a reflector or flash (if your camera has a flash sync) to add fill light to your scene.
8. **Pay attention to your metering**: If your camera has a built-in meter, use it to gauge the light. If not, use an external light meter or estimate the exposure based on your experience. Bracket your shots to ensure you capture the desired exposure.
9. **Shoot in black and white**: Black and white film can be more forgiving in low light, as it doesn't require the same level of color accuracy. This can be a great way to add a timeless, classic feel to your images.
10. **Experiment and practice**: Low-light photography can be unpredictable, so be prepared to experiment and try different techniques. Practice will help you develop your skills and find what works best for you and your camera.
11. **Consider pushing or pulling your film**: If you're comfortable with film development, you can push or pull your film to adjust the exposure. This can help rescue underexposed or overexposed images.
12. **Scan and edit digitally**: If you're not comfortable with darkroom processing, consider scanning your negatives and editing them digitally. This can help you adjust the exposure, contrast, and color balance to enhance your low-light images.

By following these tips, you'll be well on your way to capturing stunning low-light images with your vintage Canon rangefinder. Happy shooting!
